subject: Report many claimable pseudo-VFs
commit_message:
Report many claimable pseudo-VFs

As we understand more about how PCI claims work, it becomes clear that
each "device" we report in pci_passthrough_devices via
get_available_resource can only be used once.  After that, it is
"allocated" and filtered out of subsequent requests.

Because we carve out VFs on the fly, and the capacity may vary, we don't
know exactly how many VFs we will be able to create on a given port.
However, we have an upper bound: MaxSupportedEthernetLogicalPorts.
We're willing to let the plug (rather than the Claim) fail if we hit
some other limit (e.g. capacity).

So this change set fixes driver.get_available_resource (via
host.build_host_resource_from_ms, via a new helper _build_pci_json) to
generate and report MaxSupportedEthernetLogicalPorts pseudo-VFs for each
physical port, for each SR-IOV card.

(We don't intend to try matching up which physical port is being
depleted on the consuming side, since set_vnic_back_devs always tries to
do this as efficiently as possible.)

Change-Id: I2dddcfd782574b75236e5abfbb7e4d86a11d0929

subject: Glare
commit_message:
Glare

Glare (from GLance Artifact REpository) is a service that
provides access to a unified catalog of structured
meta-information as well as related binary data
(these structures are also called 'artifacts').

Glare offers its users a number of important features, like:
 * Custom assets — it's not just images anymore, but also Heat
   templates, Murano packages, Mistral workbooks, Tacker
   blueprints and so on.
 * Artifacts versioning — each artifact can be supplemented
   with the version in SemVer format.
 * Support of multiple binary objects per artifact. From
   Glare’s part, it allows to specify a set of such attributes.
 * Structured properties — artifacts may contain structured
   properties like ‘dict’ and ‘list’.
 * Dependencies between artifacts — one artifact may depend on
   the other.
 * Additional filtering for artifacts with various operators.
 * Importing/exporting of artifacts between clouds.

bootstrap_admin_node: Fix connectivity check.

After Fuel Master builds the bootstrap image at first boot,
internet connectivity is tested using the URL for the CentOS
updates repository.

bootstrap_admin_node.sh script parses the output of `yum repolist`,
looking for entries like 'Repo-baseurl: http://...'.

However, in Fuel 9.0, <updates> points to a mirrorlist file (a text
file containing a list of possible mirror URLs) instead of being
a single, direct link to the repository.

For now, we only test that we can access the mirrorlist file,
while the check should be performed against the mirror(s).

Repo-baseurl: http://mirror.fuel-infra.org/.../updates/x86_64/

The lxc host role was being pinned to specific hosts under the assumption

subject: Changed exception catching order
commit_message:
Changed exception catching order

On [1] InstanceIsLocked is catched. However on [2] InstanceInvalidState
is catched, which is an ancestor of InstanceIsLocked.
For this reason, catching a specific exception is meaningless after
catching the base type (as it will catch sub-types too).

So I changed the order of the catch clauses, which now
catches InstanceIsLocked before InstanceInvalidState, which means
the more specific exception is catched before the more general
exception.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L1111

subject: Move properties_data into a separate table
commit_message:
Move properties_data into a separate table

Properties data (encrypted or not) is now stored in the
resource_properties_data table. We still support reading properties
data from the legacy locations (separate columns in the resource and
event tables) but all new properties data are written to
resource_properties_data.

Instead of duplicating properties data for a given resource
and its events, we refer to the same resource_properties_data
object from both resources and events.

Notes about encrypting/decrypting properties data:

1. ResourcePropertiesData methods take care of encrypting/decrypting.
2. Resource objects do not have to worry about encrypting due to 1.
2a. resource._stored_properties_data and resource.rsrc_prop_data.data
    are always decrypted (in the context of heat.engine.resource or
    heat.object.resource).
3. Previously (not anymore), heat.engine.resource would take care of
   the encrypting in _store() and _store_or_update().
4. Previously and currently, heat.object.resource decrypts the legacy
   properties_data field if needed.

Change-Id: I0c29f0235b284fdf3452cab0dd47ca48f31e70af
Closes-Bug: #1524013

test-bifrost-create-vm.yaml --syntax-check --list-tasks
No config file found; using defaults
1 plays in test-bifrost-create-vm.yaml

playbook: test-bifrost-create-vm.yaml
+ /opt/stack/ansible/bin/ansible-playbook -vvvv -i inventory/localhost
test-bifrost.yaml --syntax-check --list-tasks -e testing_user=cirros
No config file found; using defaults
9 plays in test-bifrost.yaml

playbook: test-bifrost.yaml
[...]

As a result of which, split these two steps in order for
both operations to be executed as expected.

subject: An initial commit for MuranoPL garbage collector
commit_message:
An initial commit for MuranoPL garbage collector

This is an initial commit for MuranoPL garbage collector implementation.
A first step of GC implementation is implementation of destruction
dependencies between applications. Destruction dependencies works as
described below.
Since murano still have a problem described in a spec, it was decided
to skip serialization/deserialization steps for destruction dependencies
for now at least.
If object Foo establishes such a dependency on the object Bar then:
* Foo will be notified when Bar is about to be destroyed.
* If both Foo and Bar are going to be destroyed in the same garbage
  collection execution, Bar will be destroyed before Foo.
